qas.question: How many radioisotopes of zinc have been discovered?
What is the longest half life of the isotopes?
What does the superscript m represent?
How many excited states does 61Zn have?
How many excited states does 73Zn have?
What is the most long lived radio isotope?
What is the half life of 72Zn?
How many nuclear isomers does zinc have?
What does a metastable isotope do to return to ground state from an excited state?

answers.text: emitting a photon in the form of a gamma ray

qas.question: How many radioisotopes of zinc have been hidden?
What is the only half life of the isotopes?
How many boring states does 61Zn have?
How many nuclear isomers does zinc avoid?

context: <a0_0><b10_0>Several dozen<b10_0/><a0_0/> radioisotopes have been characterized. <a5_0>65Zn<a5_0/>, which has a half-life of <a1_0><b11_0>243.66<a1_0/> days<b11_0/>, is the most long-lived radioisotope, followed by 72Zn with a half-life of <a6_0>46.5 hours<a6_0/>. Zinc has <a7_0><b13_0>10<b13_0/><a7_0/> nuclear isomers. 69mZn has the longest half-life, 13.76 h. The superscript m indicates a <a2_0><a8_0>metastable isotope<a8_0/><a2_0/>. The nucleus of a metastable isotope is in an excited state and will return to the ground state by <a9_0>emitting a photon in the form of a gamma ray<a9_0/>. 61Zn has <a3_0><b12_0>three<b12_0/><a3_0/> excited states and 73Zn has <a4_0>two<a4_0/>. The isotopes 65Zn, 71Zn, 77Zn and 78Zn each have only one excited state.
